Centro de Investigaciones en Catálisis (CICAT) and Laboratorio de Ciencia de Superficies (SurfLab), Parque Tecnológico Guatiguará, Universidad Industrial de Santander km 2 vía El Refugio Piedecuesta Santander 681011 Colombia 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. 2 https://orcid.org/0000-0001-7001-5409 3 https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8521-9922 4 https://orcid.org/0000-0003-3227-0251 Bio-oils obtained from rapid pyrolysis have emerged as a renewable energy source, but their high content of oxygenated molecules gives them unwanted properties for their use as green fuels. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is the process used to improve their quality by removing oxygen heteroatoms from them. At the research stage, HDO is commonly studied with model molecules such as guaiacol. Bimetallic supported NiCu catalysts are efficient for diverse hydrogenations. However, published studies do not allow concluding whether supported NiCu catalysts lead to green fuels which are free from oxygen heteroatoms. For this reason, we systematically studied the properties of Al2O3 and Al2O3-SiO2 supported NiCu catalysts for the HDO of guaiacol in a batch reactor at representative process conditions; 250°C and p H 2 = 6.9 MPa . In general, supported monometallic Ni catalysts were the most active among all catalysts. Furthermore, the addition of Cu promoted the formation of large Cu-rich alloy particles that decreased the apparent initial reaction rate regardless of the support. This effect was stronger when aluminosilicates were used as catalytic support. In addition, Ni was responsible for directing the reaction route towards the hydrogenation pathway in the bimetallic catalysts, while Cu monometallic catalysts followed the direct deoxygenation route. On the other hand, the modification of the support increased the formation of green cyclohexane, even in monometallic Cu catalysts, allowing to obtain a highly active and selective monometallic Ni catalyst towards the production of cyclohexane. Graphical Abstract Keywords Guaiacol Hydrodeoxygenation Ni Cu Aluminosilicates NiCu alloy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction It is well established that our dependence on fossil fuels from non-renewable sources is having dire environmental and societal consequences [1,2]. Hence, we have a pressing need to devise, design, and implement sustainable processes that are either new or compatible with our current infrastructure and technology [3,4]. In this regard, projects for producing green fuels from lignocellulosic biomass continue to be in development at both scientific and industrial levels since they are posited to be a closed cycle of generation and consumption of CO2 [3,5,6]. It is important to clarify that green fuel is different from biofuel, as the former is produced by catalytic hydrotreating, and the latter by transesterification [7,8]. One primary stage for the process is the pyrolysis of the lignocellulosic biomass. Of special interest is the rapid pyrolysis of biomass, which consists of heating it from room temperature to around 500 ºC under an atmosphere free of oxygen during times which may be as short as ∼ 1 s. Unrefined bio-oil is produced as a result of this process [9,10]. Bio-oils are a mixture of more than 300 oxygenated organic compounds that include acids, alcohols, aldehydes, ethers, ketones, and phenols [11]. This mixture has high acidity; pH 2 ∼ 4, low calorific values; 15.0–16.0 MJ/kg [12], high viscosity; 0.035 – 1.000 Pa·s at 40 °C [13] -keep in mind that a Google search informs that water has a viscosity of 0.00065 Pa·s at 25°C-, and poor thermal stability related to polymerization and polycondensation reactions that start to occur around 100 ºC [3,6]. Therefore, bio-oils must be refined to be suitable green fuels [9]. The leading technology to refine bio-oils is catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO). HDO removes oxygen heteroatoms to produce green fuels [8] using hydrogen in the presence of a catalyst in a similar way to the treatment used in the oil industry to eliminate sulfur and nitrogen [4]. Owing to the latter, hydrodeoxygenation could be done adapting the current infrastructure of the oil industry [3,4]. Most studies agree that the hydrodeoxygenation of bio-oils should be carried out in two stages [14]. The first stage aims to stabilize the most reactive compounds in the bio-oil; namely, methoxyphenols, biphenols, and ethers. According to the literature [15–17], this stage should be done between 200 and 280 ºC. The second stage is intended to convert phenolic structures into light hydrocarbons with higher calorific value through complete deoxygenation and should be carried out above 300 ºC [14–16]. The design of new catalytic phases for hydrodeoxygenation is still challenging because of a lack of full understanding of the chemistry and transport processes related to the process [18]. Catalytic studies with model molecules shed light into key aspects of the process that inspire and lead the way to more rational designs. In this sense, 2-methoxyphenol (guaiacol) and its parent substituted compounds are models of great interest for analyzing the hydrodeoxygenation of bio-oils because they are provided with two important functional groups in their structure; namely, the hydroxy-(R-OH) and the methoxy-(RO-CH3) functional groups, which tend to generate high molecular weight compounds by condensation reactions [19,20]. Besides the above and owing to the historical knowledge of catalytic refining, most literature is devoted to studying the catalytic properties of dispersed (or supported) sulfided Co–MoS2 and Ni–MoS2 phases and metallic nanoparticles in the hydrodeoxygenation of bio-oils [21–23]. Between these two, the latter seems more adequate for further technological development since handling sulfides is unpractical under the sulfur free atmosphere of hydrodeoxygenation reactors [24]. Ni (nano)particles are well known hydrogenation catalysts for edible bio-oils and fats [25–29] and are often preferred among other metallic phases because of the higher abundance of nickel on the planet. For instance, whereas the relative abundance of nickel on earth is estimated to be 84 ppm, the relative abundance of platinum is merely about 0.005 ppm; i.e., five orders of magnitude smaller [30]. Besides nickel, copper has become an important player for the hydrogenation of edible bio-oils and fats [29]. On the basis of several studies, a kind of consensus seems to have begun to build up in the open literature about the existence of synergetic effects between Ni and Cu in hydrogenation reactions. Aiming to explain such effects, claims such as the following have been made: the addition of Cu to Ni decreases the reduction temperature of Ni and thus prevents the formation of residual surface carbon [31]. Also, Cu limits the sintering of the active phase during hydrogenation reactions [24,32–34]. Another common argument to explain synergy between Ni and Cu appeals to electronic effects claiming that Cu transfers electrons from its conduction band to that of Ni hence filling the d-band of the latter [35]. Whatever reasonable these explanations may be, this synergistic effect does not seem to apply to hydrodeoxygenation which comprise coupling hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis reactions. Table 1 summarizes some selected relevant studies for this type of catalysts and compares them [24,31–40]. Among these studies, some report that supported bimetallic NiCu catalysts are more efficient than monometallic Ni catalysts. Although NiCu catalysts are believed to be superior to monometallic Ni catalysts in HDO, the studies in Table 1 mostly show that monometallic Ni catalysts exhibited similar or even better catalytic performance than the best bimetallic NiCu catalyst. It is important to emphasize that the "best" catalyst was one that not only showed a higher conversion of the oxygenated hydrocarbon but also exhibited greater selectivity toward HDO products (i.e., completely deoxygenated compounds). Some reports have presented evidence that shows that the addition of Cu on Ni catalysts does not lead to synergistic effects [31]. Also, Zhang et al. [32] and Dongil et al. [33] reported that monometallic Ni catalysts exhibited better catalytic activity in guaiacol hydrodeoxygenation than bimetallic Ni-Cu catalysts supported on ZrO2, ZrO2–SiO2 and carbon nanotubes. A few possible explanations for the latter behavior were postulated. On the one hand, Dongil et al. [33] attributed the lower performance of bimetallic Ni-Cu catalysts to the presence of a large amount of unactive NiO clusters exposed on the surface of the bimetallic catalysts that form instead of the metallic Ni moieties which constitute active sites for the HDO reaction [24]. The authors also argued that Cu induced a decrease of the particle size of Ni which was detrimental to the catalytic performance [24]. This latter argument was previously postulated by other authors [41,42]. However, the collection of results featured in Table 1 [24,31–38] evidences undeniable disparities in the reaction protocols for testing Ni-Cu catalysts that may mask the intrinsic chemistry of the catalytic process. This raises the question of whether the effect of Cu on the hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol over NiCu bimetallic catalysts is associated with a shift in the metal particle size distribution, whether this effect is influenced by the nature of the support, or if it is simply an apparent effect resulting from the differing reaction conditions employed in previously reported studies. Considering the evidence discussed above, we sought to understand the catalytic properties of Ni-Cu catalysts on the hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol in a systematic manner. For this purpose, we synthesized a series of catalysts with different Cu/(Ni+Cu) ratios; namely, 0.00, 0.25, 0.50, 0.75, and 1.00 and supported them over three different carriers: a commercial Al2O3 and two aluminosilicates. These catalysts were tested in the hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol using a batch reactor operated at 250 °C and pH2 = 6.9 MPa, and their catalytic performance was analyzed in terms of key physicochemical properties; namely: textural properties, composition and morphology of the metallic particles and reducibility of the catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Reactants The reactants used in this research were: tetraethyl orthosilicate (Si(OC2H5)4, Sigma-Aldrich, 98 %), γ-Al2O3 (commercial grade, Procatalyse), ethanol (C2H6O, Merck, absolute for analysis), nickel (II) nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O, Merck, 99 %), copper (II) nitrate (Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O, Merck, 99 %), ammonia solution (NH4OH, Merck, 29 %), hydrofluoric acid (HF, Merck, 40 %), nitric acid (HNO3, Merck, 69 %), potassium bromide (KBr, Merck, 99.99 %), guaiacol (C7H8O2, Sigma-Aldrich, 99 %), dodecane (C12H26, Sigma-Aldrich, 99 %), xylene "mixture of isomers" (C8H10, JT Baker, 98.5 %), pyridine (C5H5N, Sigma-Aldrich, 99 %), acetic acid (CH3COOH, Merk, 99 %) that contained traces of dioxane according to GC-MS results (not shown), hydrogen (H2, 99.95 %, Linde), air (zero grade 4.7, 99.99 %, Messer), He (UHP, 99.99 %, Messer), and nitrogen (N2, 99,99 %, Linde). All reactants were used as received from their suppliers. 2.2 Synthesis of the catalysts Three supports were used for the synthesis of the catalysts: γ-Al2O3 and two homemade aluminosilicates. The latter were synthesized by the impregnation of tetraethyl orthosilicate over Al2O3 [43]. For this purpose, ∼4.7200 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate were dissolved in ∼22.2000 g of ethanol and this solution was mixed with ∼7.0000 g of Al2O3 powder. The produced mixture was rotary evaporated using an instrument equipped with a water bath (Büchi, R-124, B-480) and a pump (V-100) able to reach 600 mbar vacuum. The rotary evaporator was used at 70 rpm and 60 °C during 10 min, and then at 65 °C during 25 min under 300 mbar. During the process, the absence of bubbles was continuously checked to prevent boiling of the impregnating solution. The recovered solid was first dried at room temperature for 2 h and then calcined in a glass tubular reactor provided with a glass frit at 480 °C under an airflow of 100 mL/min. Supports were labeled as Al-Si( x 2 ) where x 2 corresponds to the molar fraction of SiO2 in the support; namely, 0.53 and 0.70. Further details of the preparation process can be found elsewhere [43,44]. Supported NiCu catalysts with different Cu/(Ni+Cu) molar ratios were synthesized by co-impregnating adequate solutions of Ni and Cu nitrates over the three supports mentioned earlier. Impregnation was performed by adding ∼28 mL of an ammonia solution (29 % v/v) to ∼27.8000 g of the corresponding aqueous Ni and Cu nitrate solutions to obtain the metal complex ions ([Ni(NH3)6]2+ and [Cu(NH3)4]2+), see Eqs. 1 to 4, and to achieve a fully dissolved solution with a pH higher than 12. The latter also ensured that the alumina surface was negatively charged during impregnation thus adsorbing the cationic metal complexes via electrostatic interaction [43–45]. (1) N i 2 + ( aq ) + 2 N H 3 ( aq ) + 2 H 2 O ( l ) ⇋ Ni ( OH ) 2 ( s ) + 2 N H 4 + ( aq ) (2) Ni OH 2 s + 6 N H 3 aq ⇋ Ni N H 3 6 2 + ( aq ) + 2 OH ( aq ) (3) C u 2 + ( aq ) + 2 N H 3 ( aq ) + 2 H 2 O l ⇋ Cu ( OH ) 2 ( s ) + 2 N H 4 + ( aq ) (4) Cu OH 2 s + 4 N H 3 aq ⇋ Cu N H 3 4 2 + ( aq ) + 2 OH ( aq ) After mixing the solution with the support, the produced mixture was rotary evaporated at 400 mbar, 60 °C and 80 rpm for 30 min and then at 150 mbar, 65 °C and 80 rpm for 30 min. As in the case of the synthesis of the Al-Si( x 2 ) supports, boiling of the impregnating solution was prevented at all times. The recovered solid material was then removed and left to dry at room temperature for 12 h [44]. Subsequently, in a glass tubular reactor, they were dried at 110 °C with a dry air flow of 100 mL/min for 6 h and calcined at 450 °C for 4 h using heating ramps of 2 and 4 °C/min, respectively. The metal loading of the catalysts was always adjusted to 20 wt% varying the Cu/(Ni+Cu) molar ratio from 0.00 to 1.00. To identify the catalysts, the following nomenclature was used: NiCu( x 1 )/Al-Si( x 2 ). Where, x 1 refers to the nominal Cu/(Ni+Cu) molar ratio of the materials. Monometallic Ni catalysts, i.e., x 1 = 0.00 , were labeled as Ni/Al-Si( x 2 ), whereas monometallic Cu catalysts, x 1 = 1.00 , were labeled as Cu/Al-Si( x 2 ). 2.3 Assessment of the physicochemical properties of the materials The following were considered to be key physicochemical properties of the catalysts: acidity of the supports, texture and metallic particle size distributions, porosity and surface area, bulk chemical structure, chemical composition of metallic particles, and the metallic phase reducibility. The chemical structure of the supports was evaluated by attenuated total reflectance (ATR) using a Nicolet iS50 Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer (ThermoScientific). The acidity of the catalysts was evaluated after recording the infrared spectra of adsorbed pyridine. Analyses were performed with the Nicolet iS50 spectrometer mentioned earlier. The setup for the adsorption stage consisted of a vacuum resistant glass cell attached to a T-shaped sampling zone with two parallel windows of zinc selenide and a Pfeiffer Hicube Eco Turbo Pumping Station that reaches a pressure of 1 × 10−4 Pa [46,47]. For the supports, the samples of the materials, previously grounded to obtain fine particles, were pressed (4.5 tons) onto wafers ( ∼ 0.0200 g, ∼9 mm diameter) and placed in the cell for analysis. For the catalysts, ∼0.0200 g of a mixture catalyst:KBr = 20:80 were pressed (4.0 tons) onto a wafer of similar size and diameter as the supports. KBr was previously dried in a static oven at 60 °C for 24 h. Samples were first degassed under vacuum (ca. 1 ×10−6 mbar) at 450 °C for 4 h. After cooling the cell to room temperature, a first spectrum of each outgassed sample was recorded and used as a reference. Then, samples were exposed to 30 mbar of pyridine for 15 min at 150 °C. After pyridine exposure, samples were degassed for 1 h at 150 °C to desorb pyridine. FT-IR spectra were recorded after each desorption stage. Based on the acquired data, the relative density of either Brønsted or Lewis acid sites was estimated using Eq. 5 [47,48]: (5) Density of acid sites [ μ mol m 2 ] = area under the curve × wafer area weight of the dry sample × Coef . E . M . × BET surface area Where, the "area under the curve” was calculated by integrating the band of interest with units of cm−1 (1450 and 1545 cm−1 for Lewis and Brønsted sites, respectively) [48]. The “weight of the dry sample” (after the test) is given in grams, and the molar extinction coefficient, “Coef. E.M.”, is the integrated molar extinction coefficient [48] obtained by Beer’s law [48,49]. Herein, values of 1.67 and 2.22 cm/μmol were used for the Brønsted and Lewis site bands, respectively [48]. In the cited paper, these values were calculated using 5 zeolites (mordenite, Y, and ZSM-5) and two amorphous silica-alumina (ASA). Owing to the latter, the results presented herein must be interpreted in a semi-quantitative manner only. Because the catalysts were very dark due to their metal loading, ca. 20 wt%, the signal intensity during FTIR examination was low, thus preventing the detection of Brønsted acid sites. Spectra recorded from some catalysts are presented in Section SI_9. The porosity and specific surface area of the materials were estimated from data produced after recording adsorption-desorption isotherms of nitrogen at −196 °C. Tests were done with a 3Flex instrument (Micromeritics) taking ∼ 40 points within a p / p 0 range going from ∼8 × 10−6 to 0.99, using an equilibrium interval of 10 s. Before each test, ca. ∼ 0.2000 g of the sample were degassed under vacuum (∼7 Pa) for 1 h at 100 °C and 16 h at 300 °C. Calculations were made to estimate the specific surface area (SABET), pore volume (PV), and average pore diameter (DP) of the materials from the recorded data. The specific surface area was determined using the method of Brunauer, Emmett, and Teller [50] after applying the Rouquerol criteria to select the experimental points where the CBET constant is minimized [51]. The volume and average pore diameter were calculated using the desorption branch of the isotherm to apply the Barret, Joyner, and Halenda method (BJH) [52] using the Harkins and Jura thickness curve [53,54], and the so-called Faas correction. Further details on the calculations and on the precision of the instrument can be found elsewhere [55,56]. All calculations were done with the MicroActive® Interactive Data Reduction and Control Software of the instrument. An analysis of the chemical structure of the catalysts was done by collecting X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns with a D8 advance X-ray diffractometer (Bruker) provided with Cu Kα1 radiation. XRD patterns were recorded between 2θ angles of 4.0–70.0 with a 0.02 step size. Samples were ground, mixed with paraffin and mounted on a sample holder. For the activate catalysts, samples were reduced ex-situ under a 100 mL/min H₂ flow at 350 °C for 4 h in a quartz fixed-bed U-tube reactor (0.7 cm inner diameter) equipped with quick connectors for isolation. Once the reduction treatment was completed, the samples were cooled to room temperature under the same H₂ flow mentioned earlier and then rapidly transferred to a glove box under a N₂ atmosphere. The average crystallite size for XRD detected NiO and CuO phases in the catalysts were estimated with the Scherrer equation [57] (Eq. 6). (6) D = κ λ β cos θ Where, D is the crystallite size, λ is the wavelength of X-ray ( κ = 0.15405 nm for Cu Ka), β is the FWHM in radians, κ is the shape factor, normally taken as 0.9, and θ is the diffraction angle. For NiO, the crystallite size was obtained by averaging the values obtained with the XRD peaks at 2θ of 37.2, and 43.4°, which correspond to the diffraction planes for NiO(111) and NiO(200), respectively [58]. For CuO, we averaged the values obtained with the XRD peaks at 2θ of 35.5 and 38.7°, which correspond to the diffraction planes for CuO(-111) and CuO(111), respectively [59]. All values are presented in the supporting information SI_5. The morphology and distribution of particle sizes of the metallic phase of the catalysts were assessed from high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) images acquired with a JEOL 2100 Plus UHR microscope operated at 200 kV. The powdered samples were dispersed in ethanol, and then a drop from this suspension was evaporated on a carbon-coated copper grid or a carbon-coated gold grid. Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) images using a high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) detector were also acquired in some instances. The image contrast in this mode is strongly correlated to the atomic number: heavier elements contribute to brighter contrast (Z-contrast). The relative chemical composition of the metallic particles was assessed with an energy dispersive X-ray (EDX, Oxford Instruments X-Max 80 SDD) spectrometer attached to the microscope column. To obtain sufficient counts for the chemical analysis, a probe size of 2 nm was used, see supplementary information SI_1. Prior to the analysis, samples were reduced ex-situ in a quartz fixed bed U–tube reactor with 100 mL/min of H2 (ALPHAGAZ 1, Air Liquide) at 350 °C for 4 h. The average particle size was determined by the volume average diameter ( d mean , vol ) [60], see Eq. 7. (7) d mean , vol = ∑ i d i 4 ∑ i d i 3 Where, di is the particle diameter. The reduction profiles for samples of the catalysts were recorded by H2 temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments. TPR tests were done with a CATLAB system coupled to a QGA mass spectrometer -MS- (Hiden Analytical). The MS was equipped with both an internal dual electron multiplier detector, SEM (1 ×10−12 - 1 ×10−7), and a Faraday (1 ×10−8 - 1 ×10−5) detector, and with a precision quartz inlet heated capillary (QIC) sampling interface. For the tests, samples of ca. 0.1000 g were loaded in a straight quartz tube (0.7 cm i.d.) and pretreated with a 50 mL/min flow of argon at 300 °C for 90 min at 5 °C/min. After cooling down to 70 °C, the reactor was fed with 1 mL/min H2, 47 mL/min of Ar and 2 mL/min of He used as an internal standard, while the temperature was increased at 3 °C/min and up to 800 °C. The consumption of hydrogen (m/z = 2) and the production of water (m/z = 18) were followed on-line with the MS. Mass flow controllers (Bronkhorst) were controlled using the CATLAB software. Finally, the chemical composition and electronic state of the elements that constitute the surface of the catalysts were determined by XPS using the XPS/ISS/UPS - ACenteno (SPECS) surface characterization platform located at Laboratorio Central de Ciencia de Superficies (SurfLab-UIS). The platform is equipped with a PHOIBOS 150 analyzer, a 2D-CMOS detector, and a dual monochromatic Al/Ag X-ray source (FOCUS 500). The limit of detection of the instrument is ∼0.01 % molar concentration. Prior to analysis, samples were reduced ex-situ under a 50 mL/min H₂ flow at 350 °C for 4 h in a quartz fixed-bed U-tube reactor (0.7 cm inner diameter) equipped with quick connectors for isolation. Once the reduction was complete, the samples were cooled to room temperature under the same H₂ flow and rapidly transferred to a glove box under a N₂ atmosphere. Inside the glove box, the samples were grinded in an agate mortar to homogenize their grain size distribution. The recovered powder was deposited on stainless steel sample holders using Cu conductive adhesive tape. Then, the samples were introduced to the loading chamber of the platform where they were kept until the chamber reached a pressure of 1 × 10−5 Pa. Afterwards, samples were transferred to the analysis chamber via a linear central vacuum tube. Measurements were carried out in the analysis chamber at a pressure of ∼1 × 10−7 Pa. For each sample, the spectra were recorded using a monochromatic Al Kα source (hυ = 1486.6 eV) operated at 12 kV and 200 W. On the other hand, the compensation of the surface charge of the samples was controlled with an electron gun (Flood Gun - FG 15/40-PS FG500) using a 94 μA of current and a voltage of 3.6 eV. The following sequences of spectra were recorded: general spectrum, C 1 s, O 1 s, Cu 2p, Ni 2p, Al 2p + Ni 3p + Al 2 s + Si 2p + Si 2 s + valence band and C 1 s again to verify the stability of the surface charge as a function of time. The general spectra were recorded at a pass energy of 100 eV, whereas high resolution spectra were recorded at a pass energy of 20 eV. For quantification, only the signals corresponding to O 1 s, Al 2p, Si 2p, C 1 s, Cu 2p and Ni 2p were taken into account. Data analysis was done with the CasaXPS® program (Casa software Ltd). The Scofield library provided by CasaXPS® was used for fixing the values of the Response Sensitivity Factors (RSF) for each core level. The intensity of the spectra was calibrated according to the ratio of the escape depth and the −0.7414 power of the kinetic energy to the magic angle ratio. The binding energy scale for the spectra was corrected by fixing the binding energy of the Al 2p peak at 74.5 eV [61].This strategy was adopted because Al 2p is a more stable peak regarding charging effects during analyses [62]. Peak decomposition was done using a U 2 Tougaard base line to model the background of the spectra. On the other hand, peak components were modelled with LA(x,y,z) line shapes also provided by the software. This kind of line shape allows for modelling peak asymmetries that are inherent to the instrumental set-up and to the chemical state of the elements [62–64]. Tables S5 summarizes the results of the spectra fitting for each of the analyzed materials 2.4 Catalytic tests Catalytic tests were done following protocols described in previous studies from our research group [14,19]. Tests were done with a 500 mL stainless-steel batch reactor (Parr series 4570/80) operated at 250 °C, p H 2 = 6.9 MPa , and agitation speed of 750 rpm. The reactor feed (210 mL) was composed of 3.7 wt% guaiacol, 2.0 wt% of dodecane which was used as an internal standard for chromatographic analysis of the reaction products, and 94.3 wt% xylene used as solvent. Before each test, ca. 1.5000 g of the catalyst to be tested (0.18 mm < particle diameter < 0.3 mm) were activated ex-situ under a flow of 100 mL/min of H2 at 350 °C for 4 h in a quartz fixed bed U–tube reactor (0.7 cm ID) equipped with quick connectors for insulation. The catalyst/guaiacol weight ratio used in the experiments was 0.21. The reactor was sealed immediately after adding the activated catalyst to the reaction mixture. The air trapped inside the reactor was evacuated by making a pressurization-depressurization cycle of N2 (1.4 MPa) and verifying the absence of leaks. Then, the reactor was heated to 250 °C under constant stirring. Once the latter temperature was reached, H2 was added to the reactor until reaching the reaction pressure. Samples of the reaction products were taken periodically during the tests. The first sample, assumed as a reference for zero reaction time, was taken immediately after pressurizing the reactor with H2. Then, samples of the reaction products were taken successively at 10, 25, 40, 55, 75, 95, 115, 155, 195, and 240 min. The collected liquid samples were analyzed with an HP 6890 gas chromatograph equipped with an FID detector and an HP-1 column (100 m × 0.25 mm × 0.5 μm). The split-splitless device of the instrument entry was operated at 200 ºC, 2.4 bar, and 85.914 cm3/min of He. The oven of the instrument was programmed with a temperature ramp starting at 90 ºC and then rising temperature to 130 ºC. The latter condition was held for 0.5 min. Afterwards, the temperature was raised to 180 °C and held at that value for 0.5 min. Finally, the oven was heated to 220 ºC and held for 3.0 min. The heating rate used in each stage was 5 °C/min. An identification of some reaction products; cyclohexane, toluene, cresol, phenol, and catechol was carried out by comparing their retention times with those of the respective gas chromatography standards and their quantification was carried out using the corresponding calibration curves. Other reaction products; namely, cyclohexanol, 1,2 dimethoxybenzene and methoxycyclohexanol were identified by GC-MS analysis using an HP-1 column and the same protocol described for the analysis of the samples with the HP-5 column. The relative concentration of the latter in the liquid products was estimated using the chromatographic response factor of the compound whose retention time was closer to it. Therefore, the response factor of catechol was used to estimate the relative concentration of cyclohexanol and methoxycyclohexanol. Also, the response factor of guaiacol was used for estimating the relative concentration of 1,2 dimethoxybenzene. An analysis of the possible influence of mass and heat transport limitations on the catalytic behavior was made. The analysis was carried out with samples of the catalyst Ni/Al-Si(0.53), since this catalyst performed best during the study (see Results and discussion section). The Madon-Boudart criterion [65], which is based on the Koros-Nowak criterion [66], was used for the analysis. The results of these tests allowed ruling out the influence of heat transport limitations but not diffusion limitations, see section SI_2. Although, provided that the hydrodynamic conditions and the porosity of the catalysts were similar (as we will discuss in the Results and discussion section), we assumed that the performance of the catalysts can be compared on the same grounds. In general, the analysis of catalytic data presented herein is based on apparent initial reaction rates (see Table S2) which correspond to a convolution of intrinsic chemical rates and diffusion rates; the latter assumed to be the same for all catalysts. It was observed that some of the synthesized catalysts hydrogenated the solvent (xylene) forming dimethylcyclohexane. Therefore, to rule out cracking of xylene to cyclohexane, an additional xylene hydrogenation test was performed with a sample of NiCu(0.25)/Al2O3. The results of this test only showed the formation of hydrogenation products of xylene and ethylbenzene (solvent impurity); i.e., dimethylcyclohexane and ethylcyclohexane, after almost 100 % conversion of xylene was completed in 4 h of reaction. The metrics used for assessing the catalytic performance were: (i) guaiacol conversion (Xgua), Eq. 8, (ii) molar yield towards the different reaction products j (Yj), Eq. 9, and (iii) the apparent initial reaction rate of guaiacol (r0 gua), Eq. 10. (8) X gua = Initial moles of guaiacol − moles of guaiacol in a t ime t Initial moles of guaiacol (9) Y j = Moles of product j in a time t Initial moles of guaiacol (10) r gua 0 = − d C gua dt Where, d C gua corresponds to the change in guaiacol molar concentration (μmol/mL) during the first 10 min of reaction (2 points), see Tables S2 and S3. 3 Results and discussion In this section, we first present the physicochemical properties of the supports and catalysts. We then discuss the influence of metal phase composition on the reactivity and selectivity of the catalysts in the HDO of guaiacol. 3.1 Physicochemical properties of the supports 3.1.1 Chemical structure Fig. 1 shows the ATR infrared spectra recorded for the supports within the wavenumber range between 400 and 1400 cm−1. The spectra recorded for the aluminosilicates showed a band between 1000 and 1100 cm−1 that was attributed to the stretching of the Si-O-Si group from the silica formed after impregnating TEOS on the surface of the alumina [67]. The intensity of this signal increased with the relative concentration of the impregnated silicon hence being greater for Al-Si(0.70) than for Al-Si(0.53). The concentration of OH groups from the Al2O3 decreased owing to their consumption by silicon. Instead, external Si-OH groups were formed, see spectra for the hydroxyl region (3660–3850 cm−1) in the supplementary information (Figure S17). This evidence showed that the aluminosilicate supports consist of a SiO2-Al2O3 oxide. 3.1.2 Textural properties Fig. 2 presents the recorded N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the supports and Table 2 shows their textural properties. In general, all the supports showed similar type IV(a) isotherms with an H2(b) hysteresis loops associated with capillary condensation in mesopores (2.5 nm < pore diameter < 50 nm), typical of Al2O3. These hysteresis loops are also attributed to pore blockage forming bottleneck-shaped cavities [68]. A decrease in the specific surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter was observed after impregnating silica. Such a decrease increased with the relative concentration of SiO2. Despite such a trend, the preservation of the hysteresis loop shape exhibited by the materials, Fig. 2, indicated that SiO2 was homogeneously distributed over the Al2O3 carrier. Pore size distributions also indicated that SiO2 occupied the largest pores of the alumina; those with an average pore diameter larger than 10 nm, see inset in Fig. 2 and numerical data in Table 2. We safely conclude thus that the three supports used to disperse the NiCu nanoparticles shared a similar pore network hence such a factor will not influence the behavior among the catalysts. 3.1.3 Acidity of the supports Fig. 3 presents FT-IR spectra within the wavenumber range between 1400 and 1600 cm−1 recorded after desorbing pyridine at 150 °C from samples of the supports. In general, pyridine is protonated when it interacts with Brønsted acid sites (BAS) resulting in a band at 1545 cm−1 (mode ν8a) and coordinately linked with acid Lewis-type sites giving rise to a band at 1455 cm−1 (mode ν19b) [69,70]. The band observed at 1490 cm−1 is characteristic of the ν19a mode at the Brønsted acid sites and the Lewis acid site, although its sensitivity to BAS concentration is greater [71]. Table 3 shows the density of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites calculated after numerically analyzing the aforementioned bands. Fig. 3 and Table 3 show that the incorporation of SiO2 proportionally decreased the Lewis acidity of the Al2O3 carrier. This type of behavior has been observed before [72]. Indeed, the occupation of the Lewis acid sites from the alumina support by the impregnated silica is similar to what was observed after impregnating Na and K on this same carrier [14,19]. On the other hand, the Brønsted acid sites that were found for the aluminosilicates were similar to those reported by Mouat et al. [73] and Ardagh et al. [74]. Considering the above findings, we may conclude that the three supports used to disperse the NiCu nanoparticles do not differ importantly in their porosity but in their acid nature. Particularly, the Lewis acidity of the Al2O3 that was used as a base to synthesize the two Al-Si( x 2 ) aluminosilicates was partially replaced by Brønsted acid sites contributed by the Si-Al-O moieties that were formed after silicon impregnation. 3.2 Physicochemical properties of the catalysts 3.2.1 Textural properties Fig. 4 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the synthesized catalysts and Table S1 summarizes their textural properties. In general, all the catalysts kept the IUPAC type IV isotherms of their parent supports, see Fig. 2 [68]. On the other hand, monometallic Cu catalysts maintained the shape of the support hysteresis loop, whereas for the aluminosilicates this shape changed from an IUPAC H2(b) type to an IUPAC H2(a) type as the Cu molar fraction decreased. In addition, the catalysts synthesized with the aluminosilicates displayed narrower pore size distributions as the Cu molar fraction decreased, see Figure S16, due to a blockage of the larger pores of the support. This may be because metal particles organized into the larger pores creating a higher number of smaller pores. As we will discuss later in Section 2.2.2, as the Cu fraction increased, larger metal particles were obtained. These particles primarily blocked small pores, thus producing pore size distributions similar to those of the original supports. Owing to the latter, the shape of the hysteresis loops remained the same as compared to the ones recorded for the parent catalytic supports. As the Cu fraction decreased, smaller particles localized inside the pores, but without completely blocking them, thereby reducing the pore size. In all cases, the surface area decreased relative to the support due to the occupation of the pores with the deposited metal particles, see Table S1. This trend led to a decrease in the amount of N2 adsorbed at low relative pressures (< 0.20), Fig. 4. For the aluminosilicates, the surface area was higher with decreasing Cu fraction, see Fig. 5, with the monometallic Ni catalysts having the highest surface area (174 m2/g) [56,68,75]. For the Al2O3 supported catalysts, the nominal Cu fraction did not influence the surface area. As shown in Fig. 4 and Table S1, Al2O3 had a higher porosity (272 m2/g) and larger pores (∼ 9 nm) than the other supports. Therefore, regardless of how the metallic particles were distributed in size, the surface area of all of the Al2O3 supported catalysts was similars. In contrast, the catalysts with the highest SiO2 loading (Al-Si(0.70)) that showed the largest reduction in surface area because their support showed smaller pores which are easier to block. In general, it is a known fact that metals consume hydroxyl groups during impregnation [45,76–79]. This was indeed the principle used to synthesize the catalysts featured in this paper, see Experimental section. Therefore, the trends found in this section can be interpreted as follows. First, the slight changes in porosity and surface area of the catalysts supported on Al2O3 follows the richness of surface hydroxyls available at the surface of this oxide [80–84]. As these hydroxyls are partly consumed during silica impregnation, the metals will tend to deposit over the remaining hydroxyls belonging to the aluminosilicate supports. However, once these hydroxyls become saturated the metals will tend to deposit unselectively over the remaining non-hydroxyl surface moieties including on top of other deposited metal ions that already reside on the surface of the support. Such process will break the uniformity of the distribution of the impregnated metals hence clogging the porous structure of the catalysts. Looking at the trends in the loss of surface area for the catalysts supported on the Al2O3 and on the two aluminosilicates, the latter process occurs more intensively during the impregnation of NiCu over the two aluminosilicates. Furthermore, the process is more impactful as the relative concentration of Cu increased. We will show the importance of the latter when we discuss the distribution of nanoparticle sizes and compositions in the reduced catalysts. 3.2.2 Properties of the metallic phases 3.2.2.1 Crystallinity Before analyzing the properties of the nanoparticles of the catalysts after reduction and prior to the catalytic tests, we will address the crystallinity of the materials after air calcination. Fig. 6a presents the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the calcined catalysts synthesized using the Al-Si(0.53) support. We use these patterns to represent the behavior of all calcined catalysts owing to their similarities. The other XRD patterns can be found in the Supplementary Information SI_5. In general, all the catalysts showed diffraction peaks at 46° and 67° corresponding to the (400) and (440) crystal planes of γ-Al2O3, respectively [85]. No peaks associated to SiO2 were observed, see Figure S18. Monometallic Cu catalysts showed peaks at 2θ values of 33°, 35°, 39°, 49°, and 62° ascribed to the CuO(110), (-111), (111), (-202), and (-113) crystal planes, respectively [59]. These peaks decreased their intensity when the Cu molar fraction decreased, Fig. 6. On the other hand, monometallic Ni catalysts showed peaks at 37°, 43°, and 63° corresponding to the NiO(111), (200), and (220) crystal planes, respectively [58]. The intensity of these peaks also decreased after lowering the values of the Ni molar fraction. In addition, we found diffraction peaks associated to the Ni and Cu metallic particles present in the bimetallic catalysts. These particles were identified because their corresponding diffraction peaks were located at intermediate 2Θ° values between those associated with NiO and CuO, Figure S18. This suggests the existence of particles from a Ni-Cu nanoalloy. On the other hand, Fig. 6b shows the diffraction patterns of the catalysts supported on the Al-Si(0.53) aluminosilicate after the activation process. The catalysts retained the characteristic diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 at 46° and 67°, while the reflection at 38°, corresponding to the (311) plane of γ-Al2O3 [86], became more pronounced. Monometallic Cu catalysts exhibited peaks at 2θ values of 43° and 50° corresponding to the (111) and (200) crystal planes of metallic Cu, respectively [87]. On the other hand, monometallic Ni catalysts showed peaks at 44° and 52° assigned to the (111) and (200) crystal planes of Ni, respectively [88]. Additionally, small shoulders at approximately 43° and 63°, attributed to NiO, were observed, indicating that Ni was not fully reduced under the applied conditions. This aspect is discussed in detail in section 2.2.2.4. For the bimetallic catalysts, diffraction peaks located between the positions of the Ni and Cu reflections, similar to those observed in the calcined samples, Fig. 6a, confirmed the formation of a NiCu alloy that persisted after reduction. The existence of such an alloy was further corroborated by TEM analysis, reduction profiles, and XPS measurements, presented in the following sections. 3.2.2.2 Study of the reduced metallic phases of the catalysts The morphology and composition of the NiCu phases of the activated catalysts were assessed after taking multiple TEM micrographs and making chemical analysis from EDX spectra. For the sake of brevity, we left the corresponding images to Supplementary Information section; see Figures S1 to S14 and S35 to S37. In what follows, we present the statistical analysis of the recorded data. Fig. 7a shows the metal particle size distribution of the catalysts using box and whiskers plots, where the "x" mark inside the boxes corresponds to the average of the data, while the horizontal division of the boxes represents the median, and the points outside the whiskers of the plot are outliers [89]. These diagrams allowed to observe that the distribution of the metallic particle size does not follow a normal distribution. On the contrary, they present a right tail that is larger for catalysts with a greater number of outliers, see Figures S35 to S37. Fig. 7b also shows the volumetric average particle diameter obtained from the TEM images. For the Al2O3 supported catalysts, the average particle diameter was similar in all cases. However, for the catalyst with the highest Cu content, NiCu(0.75)/Al2O3, a broader particle size distribution was observed, represented by a larger box and a median farther below from the average of the data, see Fig. 7a. For the catalysts supported on aluminosilicates, taller boxes were observed with median values farther from the average and a greater presence of outliers when the nominal Cu(Ni+Cu) molar ratio was larger. Furthermore, these samples showed a relatively larger number of outliers belonging to large metallic particles. This indicates the existence of broader metallic particle size distributions skewed to larger particle sizes. This effect was more accentuated for the support with the highest SiO2 content, Al-Si(0.70), e.g., for the Si-Al(0.70) support, particles up to 65 nm were found for the monometallic Cu catalyst and 55 nm for the bimetallic NiCu(0.75) catalyst, while for the monometallic Ni catalyst, the largest particle that was measured had 28 nm. Further evidence showed an increase in the average particle diameter for the catalysts with higher Cu content, NiCu(0.75), see Fig. 7b. In addition, the formation of a Ni-Cu alloy was evidenced regardless of the support, see Fig. 8, where the concentration of the Ni and the size of the bimetallic nanoparticles were negatively correlated. The latter can be interpreted as if smaller nanoparticles were richer in Ni (Cu/(Ni+Cu) between 0.16 and 0.40), while larger nanoparticles were richer in Cu (Cu/(Ni+Cu) between 0.50 and 0.96). Trends of the same nature have been reported for NiCu catalysts supported on other carriers. For example, Dongil et al.[33] synthesized NiCu catalysts supported on carbon nanotubes with Cu loadings ranging from 1.50 to 3.75 wt%. The authors observed that increasing Cu above 3 wt% (Ni/Cu atomic ratio of 0.014) led to an increase in the metal particle size from 6.4 to 8.9 nm when the Cu loading reached 3.75 wt%. However, below 3 wt%, the addition of Cu reduced the particle size considering that their monometallic Ni catalyst showed the largest average particle size (14 nm). Since our study employs supports with different physicochemical properties and a significant higher Cu content than those used by Dongil et al. [33], it is difficult to establish whether, using our synthesis conditions and supports, the same trend would be observed at low Cu loadings. Although, according to Fig. 8, at low Cu loadings, the NiCu alloy may exhibit smaller particle sizes. Fig. 7 shows that the formation of larger particles is more evident in catalysts synthesized using aluminosilicate supports. As discussed in previous sections, aluminosilicates possess a lower density of accessible surface hydroxyl groups, owing to the partial coverage of alumina hydroxyls by silica, see Figure S17. This limited availability of hydroxyl sites leads to non-selective metal deposition on non-hydroxyl surface moieties and on pre-deposited metal species, ultimately resulting in increased particle size and broader particle size distributions. In contrast, γ-Al2O3 provides a higher concentration of surface hydroxyls, promoting a more uniform and controlled dispersion of metal ions. This behavior is consistent with reports by Pomp et al.[92], Sterrer and Freund [93], and Louwerse et al. [94], who observed that sintering of metal nanoparticles proceeds more slowly on hydroxylated surfaces. Moreover, the larger particles observed in the samples also exhibited higher Cu content. This may be attributed to the lower cohesion energy of Cu (3.49 eV/atom) compared to Ni (4.44 eV/atom) [95], which facilitates atom detachment and promotes surface migration. Additionally, previous studies have shown that Cu exhibits a higher atomic dissociation and diffusion barrier on oxide surfaces (1.23 eV) than Ni (0.86 eV), enhancing the mobility of Cu atoms and accelerating particle growth [96]. As a result, during thermal treatments such as drying, calcination, and reduction, Cu-rich alloy particles may have served as nucleation centers for migrating Cu species, leading to the formation of large Cu-enriched NiCu alloy particles. Fig. 9 shows the average crystallite size of NiO and CuO obtained with the Scherrer equation [57] compared to the volume average diameter obtained by TEM, Eq. 7 [60], (see Figures S35 to S37) for each support (Al2O3, Al-Si(0.53) and Al-Si(0.70)) as a function of the Cu/(Ni+Cu) molar ratio. In all cases, CuO nanoparticles showed larger crystallite size than Ni monometallic catalysts, similar to the results presented in Fig. 7 and Fig. 8. Furthermore, in most of the bimetallic catalysts, the crystallite size of the Cu-rich particles was considerably larger than that of the Ni-rich particles, which is consistent with the outliers in Fig. 7. This means that the particles kept the same tendency unaltered throughout calcination and reduction. On the other hand, the trend of the average sizes observed in TEM measurements is similar to that obtained by XRD for Al2O3-supported catalysts. However, for catalysts supported on aluminosilicates with high Cu loadings, the particle sizes obtained by TEM are significantly larger. This discrepancy arises because the volumetric equation used to calculate the average diameter give greater weight to larger particles, which were more frequently seen in bimetallic catalysts with higher Cu contents and in Cu monometallic catalysts. Furthermore, the Scherrer equation generally reports a smaller effective diameter than the geometric diameter [60], which presents a greater error in the case of broader distributions. An additional factor to consider is that the peaks of the crystalline phases of γ-Al2O3 (311) and (400) at 38° and 46°, respectively, overlap with peaks of NiO (111) at 37° and metallic Cu (111) at 43°, see Fig. 6, which makes peak deconvolution difficult and can lead to an incorrect estimation of the size of the crystallites. 3.2.2.3 Reducibility Fig. 10 shows the temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) profiles of the catalysts. Monometallic Ni supported on alumina (Ni/Al2O3), Fig. 10a, showed a peak centered at 590 °C with a shoulder around 457 °C, which could correspond to the reduction of NiO phases to Ni0. The extended shape of the found reduction peak can be associated to the existence of NiO phases with different particle sizes as we evidenced in our previous analyses (Sections 2.2.2.1 and 2.2.2.2) and in the literature [24,97,98]. On the other hand, the shoulder at 457 °C, observed for Ni/Al2O3 shifted to higher temperatures for the aluminosilicates, Fig. 10b-c, probably due to the presence of metallic particles with a broader size distribution, as shown in Fig. 7 [99]. In the case of the Cu catalyst supported on alumina (Cu/Al2O3), Fig. 10a, a peak at 237 ºC was observed. This peak has been ascribed to the reduction of CuO to Cu0 [100]. Similar to monometallic Ni catalysts, two peaks at 270 and 640 °C were observed when the aluminosilicates were used as supports, Fig. 10b-c, which is attributed to the formation of the larger metal particles observed in Fig. 7. Larger particles have a lower surface-to-volume ratio, which decreases the interaction of the surface with H2, hence increasing the reduction temperature [101]. The larger distance between the two reduction peaks in the Cu catalysts may be due to the large difference in metal particle sizes (between 3 and 64 nm), while in the Ni catalysts it was between (2 and 37 nm), see Fig. 7 for comparing the aforementioned particle sizes. On the other hand, despite the support used, bimetallic catalysts present reduction peaks at temperatures that vary between those observed in the monometallic catalysts. This is observed more clearly in the catalysts supported on Al2O3 (Fig. 10a) Where, as the amount of Cu increased the peak moved to the left (closer to that of Cu). In the catalysts prepared with the aluminosilicates, Fig. 10b-c, the formation of two reduction peaks was also observed. These peaks shifted their positions along with the the Cu/(Ni+Cu) ratio towards those of the monometallic Cu catalyst. This trend indicates that both the support and the amount of Cu modify the distribution of particle sizes (as observed in Fig. 7) and reinforces the claim of the formation of a NiCu alloy observed in Fig. 6 and Fig. 8. The behavior described earlier has been explained by considering that the reduction of CuO to Cu creates more reduction centers that accelerate the reduction of NiO [38,102,103]. Herein, we cannot prove such claim, but all in all, we find that it makes chemical sense. Furthermore, van’t Blik et al. [104] and Rivero-Crespo et al. [105] have reported similar behaviors for Ru-Pt catalysts supported on activated carbon and for Co-Rh/SiO2. These authors found in both cases a reduction peak situated between those belonging to the monometallic catalysts which was ascribed to the formation of an alloy between the metals. 3.2.2.4 Chemical state Fig. 11 and Fig. 12 present the high resolution XPS spectra of Ni 2p and Cu 2p regions for the catalysts synthesized with the Al-Si(0.53) support, respectively. Table S5 summarizes the results of the fitting of the spectra for each one of the analyzed materials. Regarding Ni, Fig. 11, all samples presented a doublet in the 852.8–854.5 eV and 870.5–872.6 eV regions, corresponding to the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 orbitals of metallic Ni (Ni⁰), respectively [106,107]. Additionally, a second doublet was observed at 856.2–857.1 eV and 874.1–874.8 eV, attributable to Ni²⁺ species [107–109]. This indicates that under the conditions studied herein, it is not possible to completely reduce Ni, because part of it Ni is tightly bound to the supports hence hindering its reduction [110]. On the other hand, Fig. 12 shows the formation of a doublet in the regions of 932.3–932.9 eV and 952.1–953.1 eV, corresponding to the 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 orbitals of metallic Cu (Cu0), respectively [107,111]. In addition, in the monometallic Cu catalyst and the bimetallic NiCu catalysts with higher Cu content (NiCu(0.50) and NiCu(0.75)) an additional doublet is obtained at 935.2–936.5 eV and 955.0–956.3 eV, associated to Cu2+ species [107,111,112]. In addition, a slight shift of the peak ascribed to Ni0 shifted to a higher binding energies was observed as the Cu/(Ni+Cu) molar ratio increased, see Table S5, which is associated with increasing electron transfer from Ni to Cu in the NiCu alloy [33,35,113]. This confirms the formation of the NiCu alloy observed by TEM, XRD and reduction profiles. Fig. 13a shows the relationship between the fraction of Ni⁰ and surface Ni as a function of the Cu/(Ni+Cu) molar ratio, where it is observed that the Ni⁰/Nisuperficial ratio does not strongly depended on the amount of Cu. In fact, for Cu/(Ni+Cu) ratios ≤ 0.50, the ratio is similar to that of the monometallic Ni catalyst, ∼0.33. In the case of the NiCu(0.75)/Al-Si(0.53) catalyst, the ratio rises to 0.45. Unlike Ni, where a higher fraction of the oxide was found than metallic Ni, Cu was present mainly in the metallic state, with Cu0/Cusuperficial fractions ranging from 0.87 to 1.00, see Fig. 13b. As shown in Fig. 10b, Cu is more easily reduced than Ni, resulting in a greater proportion of metallic Cu in the synthesized catalysts. Furthermore, increasing the Cu content shifts the reduction profile toward lower temperatures, which correlates with a higher fraction of metallic Ni in the catalyst with the highest Cu content, NiCu(0.75), see Fig. 13a. As seen in Fig. 12b, the bimetallic catalyst with the lowest Cu content, NiCu(0.25), did not present Cu2+, likely because Ni, which has a higher energy d-band center (-1.37 eV [114] compared to −1.61 of Cu [115]), transfers electrons to Cu, allowing it to remain in its reduced state. This is confirmed by the movement of the valence band, see Fig. 14. With increasing Cu content, the valence band shifted toward lower binding energies, i.e., it approached the Fermi level, and is more similar to that of Cu [116]. Since the electronic state of the d-band center is influenced by the valence charge near the Fermi energy level, the movement of the valence band reflects the shift of the d-band center [113]. On the other hand, Fig. 11 shows that increasing Cu content in the catalyst lead to a more pronounced change in the background slope of the Ni 2p XPS spectrum. This effect suggests that the distribution of Ni on the catalyst surface is modified as the Cu loading increases [117]. In the case of Cu, Fig. 12, the change in the background slope is less significant, indicating that Cu is likely distributed similarly across all samples. This behavior implies that Cu is preferentially located at the outermost surface, since its background remains relatively unchanged compared to the monometallic Cu catalyst. In contrast, the more substantial changes observed in the Ni background suggest that Ni becomes increasingly covered by Cu as the Cu loading increases. This would imply that large Cu-rich particles have more Cu exposed on the surface than Ni, while Ni-rich particles have a more homogeneous distribution of metallic phases. This is consistent considering the lower cohesion energy of Cu (3.49 eV/atom) compared to Ni (4.44 eV/atom) [95], which, as previously mentioned (see section 2.2.2.2.), facilitates atom detachment and promotes surface migration. Fig. 15 shows the XPS spectra of the bimetallic catalyst NiCu(0.25) supported on Al2O3 and the two aluminosilicates, Al-Si(0.53) and Al-Si(0.70). In all cases, a similar composition of the Ni and Cu species in the catalyst was obtained, i.e., Ni0/Ni ∼0.33 and Cu0/Cu = 1.00 see Fig. 13b and Table S5. Furthermore, the change of the support did not generate the formation of Cu2+, which indicates that this is an effect solely associated with the electron mobility between Ni and Cu. Additionally, no pronounced change in the Ni 2p and Cu 2p background is observed when modifying the support, indicating that it is likely that the Ni and Cu species are distributed similarly in both supports [117]. This makes sense, considering that for the lower Cu/(Ni+Cu) ratio the particles have similar particle size distributions, see Fig. 7a. To summarize the catalyst characterization, our results showed that we synthesized NiCu catalyst supported on Al2O3 and two aluminolisicates with lower Lewis acidity and a small fraction of Brønsted acidity. All catalysts displayed broad metal particle size distributions, with the Ni catalysts having the smallest sizes and the Cu catalysts forming larger particles. The monometallic Ni catalysts showed high Ni2+ formation, implying low catalyst reducibility under the conditions used in this work, while the monometallic Cu catalyst presented a low proportion of Cu2+, indicating its greater reduction ease. For bimetallic catalysts, at low Cu loadings, the NiCu alloy exhibited smaller particle size, whereas catalysts with higher Cu contents presented larger Cu-rich particles with greater Cu exposure on the surface. Larger particles of the Cu-rich alloy were observed on the catalyst supported on the aluminosilicates. 3.3 Reactivity of the catalysts 3.3.1 Monometallic catalysts Among all catalysts, Ni/Al-Si(0.53) showed the best performance. Fig. 16 compares Ni/Al-Si(0.53) with Cu/Al-Si(0.53). Monometallic Ni/Al-Si(0.53), Fig. 16a, converted very rapidly guaiacol to cyclohexane via intermediate products such as cyclohexanol and methoxycyclohexanol. This result is particularly remarkable since complete hydrodeoxygenation was done at 250 °C instead of the 300 °C conventionally used for the process, see Table 1. Meanwhile, Cu/Al-Si(0.53), Fig. 16b, showed a maximum guaiacol conversion of 41 % and a marginal 4 % yield to cyclohexane. In all cases, monometallic Ni catalysts bested the monometallic Cu catalysts, see Fig. 16 and Figures S19 to S33. According to the products observed in Fig. 16, monometallic Ni catalysts developed a hydrogenation-mediated pathway of HDO, see Fig. 17. This makes sense if one considers the high hydrogenation capacity of Ni [118,119]. In the hydrogenation mediated route of hydrodeoxygenation, the aromatic ring of guaiacol is hydrogenated first to produce methoxycyclohexanol. This intermediate is then demethoxylated to cyclohexanol and further dehydroxylated to cyclohexane. In contrast, monometallic Cu catalysts developed the direct deoxygenation pathway. This route starts with a demethoxylation of guaiacol which is followed by dehydroxylation to produce phenol and benzene. Once deoxygenation is accomplished, the aromatic ring of the molecule is hydrogenated to produce cyclohexane [120–122]. However, this final hydrogenation step is very slow due to low capacity of Cu to hydrogenate CC bonds [123]. Previous studies on the aqueous phase hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) [123] and on the hydrodeoxygenation of HMF and furfural [118,119,124] have also shown that monometallic Cu catalysts are more selective towards hydrogenolysis reactions, while monometallic Ni catalysts are responsible for performing hydrogenation. On the other hand, Abreu Teles et al. [125] proposed that the ability of Ni to follow the deoxygenation or hydrogenation pathway in the HDO reaction of m-cresol using Ni/SBA-15 catalysts depends on the particle size. Particularly, these authors postulated that smaller particles, < 3 nm, are more selective towards the deoxygenation pathway due to an increase in their oxophilicity. Such oxophilicity stems from the presence of low coordination sites on the metal, e.g., corner and edge sites [126]. On the other hand, larger particles ( ∼ 25 nm) were more active towards the hydrogenation pathway due to the high coordination sites (face sites). Deplazes et al. [39] also observed that using Ni/SBA-15 catalysts with Ni particles around 2 nm promoted the deoxygenation pathway of m-cresol to toluene. Yan et al.[25] also confirmed this for guaiacol HDO using Ni/Beta catalysts with metal loadings between 2.3–23.4 wt% at 230 °C and 4 MPa with a WHSV = 1.3 min−1. As seen in Fig. 7, S35 and S36, monometallic Ni catalysts exhibited broad size distributions (ranging from 2 to 38 nm). Therefore, the higher initial reaction rate of monometallic Ni catalysts, see Fig. 16, could be explained by a cooperative effect between the large metal Ni particles, responsible for the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring to methoxycyclohexanol, and the small Ni particles, responsible for the hydrodeoxygenation. On the other hand, the deoxygenation ability of the catalyst also depended on the support used. Catalysts synthesized with the aluminosilicates (Al-Si(0.53) and Al-Si(0.70)) showed high selectivity towards cyclohexane, i.e., complete deoxygenation, (greater than 60 %); whereas the catalyst supported on alumina (Ni/Al2O3) produced mainly methoxycyclohexanol (34 %) and cyclohexanol (7 %), i.e., they were not able to completely deoxygenate the molecule. The effect of the support was most noticeable for the monometallic Cu catalysts. For them. only those materials supported on the aluminosilicates (Al-Si(0.53) and Al-Si(0.70)) were able to produce significant amounts of cyclohexane, see Fig. 16, S23, S28 and S33. In addition, we observed the production of phenol, which is subsequently hydrogenated to obtain cyclohexane, see Fig. 17 [25,120–122]. This last hydrogenation stage may be favored by the larger metallic particles formed when using the aluminosilicates, Figures S35-37 and Fig. 7. This fact agrees with the evidence presented by Abreu Teles et al. [125] and Fernández et al. [127] indicating that larger metallic nanoparticles decrease the energetic barrier for H2 activation and allow a higher mobility of hydrogen atoms. The influence of this support will be discussed in more detail later. In summary, monometallic Ni catalysts were more active than those of Cu. The influence of the metal on the reaction route was evident, with Ni being more selective for the hydrogen- mediated pathway, while Cu directed the reaction toward the deoxygenation route. The broad size distribution of the metal particles improved the catalytic behavior, allowing the monometallic Ni catalyst to complete the HDO of guaiacol, i.e., hydrogenate and deoxygenate the molecule toward cyclohexane. Furthermore, catalysts supported on aluminosilicates were more selective toward cyclohexane than those supported on alumina. 3.3.2 Bimetallic catalysts The evolution of the catalytic performance of all the NiCu( x 1 )/Al-Si( x 2 ) catalysts is shown in the supporting information (section SI_6). From the latter data, we plotted the apparent initial reaction rates for the series of synthesized catalysts as a function of the nominal Cu/(Ni+Cu) ratio, Fig. 18. Fig. 18 shows that in most cases, increasing the relative Cu molar ratio in the metallic phase led to a decrease in the apparent initial reaction rate. In the case of catalysts supported on Al2O3, Fig. 18a, adding Cu up to a ratio of Cu(Ni+Cu) = 0.25 kept the apparent reaction rate practically the same, namely, 10.3 μmol/mL*min compared to 10.1 μmol/mL*min for the monometallic Ni catalyst, see Table S2. For higher Cu/(Ni+Cu) ratios, the apparent initial rate decreased with increasing the molar ratio, similar to the aluminosilicates. Therefore, we observed a negative influence of Cu on the catalytic performance. It is important to emphasize that previous reports on NiCu catalysts for HDO reactions of m-cresol [39] and anisole [40] did not consider Cu in the quantification of catalytic activity, normalizing only by the total Ni loading or the amount of Ni in the alloy because under the conditions used in those studies no catalytic activity was observed by the monometallic Cu catalysts. However, as seen in Fig. 16, S23, S28 and S33, under the conditions used in our work, Cu was able to convert guaiacol (up to 40 %) and even produced a small amount of cyclohexane when aluminosilicates were used as supports, see section 2.3.2.1. This indicates that, despite its low activity, the catalytic behavior of monometallic Cu catalysts in HDO reactions is dependent on its interaction with the support and on the operating conditions. Dutta et al. [128] reported that 10 wt%Cu/Al2O3 catalysts achieved up to 40 % of guaiacol conversion at 300 °C via the deoxygenation route under 6.0 MPa and a WHSV = 4–30 h−1. In contrast, at 0.5 MPa, the maximum conversion of guaiacol reached only 20 %. These findings, support the idea that, since a higher H2 pressure of 6.9 MPa was used in the present work compared to those by Deplazes et al. [39] (atmospheric pressure) and Vandevyvere et al. [40] (0.5 MPa), Cu should also be considered an active site for guaiacol conversion since it exhibits both hydrogenation and deoxygenation capabilities [128]. Fig. 19 shows the initial reaction rate as a function of the average metal particle composition determined by EDX analysis in HAADF mode. Catalysts containing Ni-rich particles exhibited higher apparent initial reaction rates. As the Cu molar ratio in the metallic particles increased, a decrease in the initial reaction rate was observed. As shown in Fig. 18, the NiCu(0.25)/Al₂O₃ catalyst displayed an initial reaction rate comparable to that of the monometallic Ni/Al₂O₃ catalyst. This trend was not observed for the catalysts supported on aluminosilicates. Notably, the NiCu(0.25)/Al₂O₃ catalyst features smaller Ni-rich metallic particles (Cu/(Ni+Cu) ≈ 20 %) than those observed on aluminosilicate supports, see Fig. 8 and Fig. 19. This particle composition enhances the hydrogenation capacity of the catalysts, mitigating the negative effect of Cu addition on activity. In contrast, as the Cu content increases, a clear enrichment of the metallic phase with Cu is evident, which correlates with the observed decline in catalytic activity. Dongil et al. [33] synthesized NiCu catalysts for guaiacol HDO supported on carbon nanotubes with Cu loadings between 1.00 and 3.75 wt% and metal particle sizes between 7 and 9 nm; while Zhang et al. [32] synthesized NiCu catalysts with Cu loadings between 5 % and 15 % supported on ZrO₂–SiO₂ where, despite the difficulty in measuring particle size, the formation of NiO particles up to 50 nm with highly dispersed CuO was estimated. On the other hand, as observed in section 2.2.2, the synthesized catalysts present broad particle size distributions, with high Ni contents in the alloy, which decreases with increasing Cu loading and generates the formation of larger Cu-rich NiCu alloy particles, see Fig. 8. In both the aforementioned works and the results in Fig. 18, the addition of Cu decreased the initial reaction rate of the materials compared to the monometallic Ni catalyst. Therefore, we may consider that the evidence collected to this point is strong enough to support the claim that, regardless of the support used, Cu does not contribute to improving the catalytic activity of supported Ni catalysts. And, neither do Ni-Cu based catalysts display synergistic behavior for hydrodeoxygenation. Such trends make sense from the fact that Cu had a lower hydrogenating capacity than Ni either under the conditions of the present work as well as in previous reports [118,119]. Vandevyvere et al. [40] reported that in the HDO of anisole in a fixed-bed reactor operated at 200 °C and 0.5 MPa with NiCu/Al2O3 catalysts, the addition of Cu led to higher activities compared to monometallic Ni catalysts due to the greater ease of reducing and dispersing Ni species in the presence of Cu. This greater reduction of Ni in the presence of Cu has also been observed in the studies reported in Table 1 and in section 2.2.2.3. However, the increase in catalytic activity was based solely on the Ni present within the alloy as the active site and was compared to a monometallic NiO catalyst. This disregards the fact that NiO is not active in hydrogenation reactions [33]; a fact that we ourselves could ratify in some tests (not shown here) where catalysts were oxidized by ambient air before starting the catalytic tests. Considering this, although the authors demonstrate that the catalytic activity of the Ni present within the alloy does increase with the Cu content, it is not clear whether the activity would be higher than that of a monometallic Ni catalyst. Furthermore, the increase in the loading of Cu in the catalyst also led to the formation of a high amount of non-active CuO within the material. According to Dongil et al. [33], the higher presence of free NiO particles is responsible for the lower conversion of the bimetallic catalysts. However, as shown in Fig. 13, for the catalysts supported on the aluminosilicate Al-Si(0.53) the surface fraction of Ni0/Nisuperficial in the bimetallic catalysts was similar to that of the monometallic one, and only slightly higher for the catalysts with higher Cu loading (NiCu(0.75)). This means that, in the catalysts synthesized in this work, the decrease in the initial reaction rate is not related to the presence of NiO particles. Instead, this decrease is probably related to the enrichment of the surface with Cu, which easily migrates to the surface and decreases the initial reaction rate of the catalysts, see section 2.2.2.4. On the other hand, the effect of Cu addition on the initial reaction rate was non-linear, see Fig. 19. This indicates that the contributions of Ni and Cu to catalytic activity are not simply additive. This behavior is due to the change Cu generates in the catalyst's selectivity, since modifying the reaction routes of guaiacol alters its apparent reaction rate [129]. Additionally, the observed trend may also suggest a support effect on catalytic performance, as the support can likewise influence reaction selectivity. 3.3.2.1 Role of the metals in catalytic selectivity Regarding selectivity, bimetallic catalysts mainly followed the pathway mediated by hydrogenation, meaning that Ni controlled the catalytic behavior. The only exception to such dominance occurred for those catalysts with the lowest Ni loading (0.25) over alumina, NiCu(0.75)/Al2O3, and provided with a lower concentration of SiO2; NiCu(0.75)/Al-Si(0.53), because these catalysts produced lower yields of 1,2 dimethoxybenzene from the deoxygenation route, Fig. 20. The latter trend can be associated with the composition of the metallic nanoparticles. Bimetallic catalysts with a lower amount of Cu; namely, NiCu(0.25) and NiCu(0.50), showed smaller particles (∼ 8 nm) of a Ni-rich Ni-Cu alloy, see Fig. 8. These bimetallic particles with a higher amount of Ni were responsible of directing the reaction through the hydrogen-mediated pathway in catalysts with a lower concentration of Cu. Instead, for higher Cu/(Ni+Cu) ratios, 1,2 dimethoxybenzene formation was observed, reaching up to 3 %yield on the NiCu(0.75)/Al2O3 and NiCu(0.75)/Al-Si(0.53) catalysts, see Fig. 20. Therefore, it is possible to conclude that the presence of Cu not only decreased the initial reaction rate of the catalysts, but also that it modified the reaction pathway towards direct deoxygenation. Deplazes et al. [39] also observed that the addition of Cu to NiCu/SBA-15 catalysts increased the production of compounds from the m-cresol deoxygenation pathway. Fig. 21 presents the selectivity plots towards methoxycyclohexanol, cyclohexanol, and cyclohexane as a function of guaiacol conversion. Regardless of the support, bimetallic catalysts with lower Cu loading showed higher selectivity for methoxycyclohexanol formation as more guaiacol was converted, indicating a decrease in the ability of the catalysts to hydrogenate the aromatic ring, see Fig. 21a–c. This may be due to the presence of larger Cu-rich particles, see Fig. 8, that present a lower d-band center than Ni-rich particles, i.e., it is farther to the Fermi level [130], see section 2.2.2.4., which weakens the binding strength of H to the metal particles and, therefore, the hydrogenation capacity [113,131,132]. In the case of the catalyst supported on Al2O3, although the catalysts with lower Cu loadings, NiCu(0.25) and NiCu(0.50), showed greater formation of methoxycyclohexanol, i.e., higher hydrogenation of the aromatic ring, the catalyst with the highest Cu content, NiCu(0.75), was the one that achieved the greatest amount of cyclohexane formation, see Fig. 21g. According to Fig. 21d, the demethoxylation of methoxycyclohexanol appears to be a rapid step that proceeds efficiently over both Ni-rich and Cu-rich particles, since the amount of cyclohexane produced was similar for all catalysts. However, only the catalyst with the presence of large Cu-rich particles was able to carry out the dehydroxylation of cyclohexanol to cyclohexane. This is because Cu is more selective towards hydrogenolysis reactions [118,119,124]. This factor could indicate that the increased amount of Cu in the catalyst is favorable for the HDO of guaiacol when Al2O3 is used as a support. However, it should be considered that these Cu-rich particles, which have a higher deoxygenation capacity, also lead to the conversion of guaiacol via the deoxygenation pathway in the NiCu(0.75)/Al2O3 catalyst, producing 1,2-dimethoxybenzene, see Fig. 20, which decreases the hydrodeoxygenation efficiency. These results suggest that the reaction on the bimetallic catalysts supported on Al2O3 occurs in two stages. Initially, guaiacol is hydrogenated primarily on the Ni-rich particles to produce methoxycyclohexanol. Subsequently, methoxycyclohexanol rapidly converts to cyclohexanol via demethylation. The ease of this demethylation step was previously reported by Tian et al. [133]. Finally, cyclohexanol converts to cyclohexane on the large Cu-rich particles. However, these large particles also lead to the transformation of guaiacol to 1,2-dimethoxybenzene via the deoxygenation pathway, see Fig. 20. 3.3.2.2 Role of the support in catalytic selectivity As mentioned in the previous sections, the catalytic activity seems to be affected not only by the composition of the metal particles but also by the support. Fig. 21 shows that cyclohexane selectivity increased considerably with the aluminosilicates, i.e., support modification mainly influences the cyclohexanol dehydroxylation step, where Al₂O₃-supported catalysts show a lower capacity to cleave the Caryl−OH bond. In fact, these catalysts were the ones with the lowest yield towards cyclohexane, see Fig. 20 and Fig. 21. This is possibly due to the presence of the Brønsted acidity in the supports generated by the external silanol groups [73,74], see Fig. 3 and Table 3, which may promote the deoxygenation reactions due to an electrophilic attack of protons at the Brønsted acid sites on the oxygen atom, allowing the formation of hydroxyl groups, which are then deoxygenated by further dehydration [25,134,135]. This step from cyclohexanol to cyclohexane via dehydroxylation was considered as the rate determining step during the HDO reaction of guaiacol using NiCo catalysts [133], possibly due to the higher dissociation energy of the Caryl-OH bond (466 kJ/mol) with respect to the Caryl-OR and Calkyl-O bonds of guaiacol, 262–276 kJ/mol, 409–421 kJ/mol, respectively [136]. In monometallic Cu catalysts, the presence of Brønsted sites on the support favors the dehydroxylation of catechol, an intermediate obtained during the first hour of reaction, see Figures S23 and S28 [25,120–122]. Subsequently, phenol is also dehydroxylated, facilitating the hydrogenation step to produce cyclohexane. It has been previously shown that the acidity of the support can play a key role in the catalytic performance of a catalyst in the hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol. For example, Lee et al.[137] compared the behavior of Ru, Pd and Rh catalysts supported on Al2O3 and a silica-alumina support (grade 135, Aldrich). The results showed that SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts presented a higher amount of strong acid sites (desorption > 400 °C), which increased the cyclohexane yield from 22 % to 60 % on Ru, from 25 % to 57 % on Rh and from 19 % to 46 % on Pd catalysts. In this case, the nature of the acid sites, i.e., Lewis or Brønsted, was not determined, therefore the influence that each of them can have on the activity of the catalysts is not known. However, Hewer et al.[138] established that in NiMo catalysts, those supported on carriers with a lower Lewis/Brønsted acid sites ratio generate a better catalytic behavior in the HDO of anisole. In fact, when Al2O3 was used as support (Lewis/Brønsted = 17.8) only phenol and cresol were obtained. Meanwhile, the use of SBA-15 (Lewis/Brønsted = 5.4) and SAPO-11 (Lewis/Brønsted = 0.3) as supports allowed to deoxygenate anisole, producing benzene, and also allowed producing cyclohexane with a selectivity of ∼ 20 %, regardless of the support. Despite these reports, to the authors' knowledge, the influence of modifying the Lewis/Brønsted site ratio of the support on the catalytic behavior of NiCu catalysts has not been reported. Yan et al.[25] and Dutta et al. [128] established that a correct balance between the acidity of the support and the quantity and size of the metal particles is required for producing efficient HDO catalysts. On the other hand, Yan et al. [25] established that the formation rate of cyclohexane has a positive relationship with the total number of acid sites. This in turn suggests that demethoxylation and dehydroxylation is catalyzed by Brønsted acid sites. In this work, a different approach was used for the synthesis of the supports, in which a small relative concentration of Brønsted acid sites was generated by the impregnation of SiO2, see section 2.1.3, while simultaneously reducing the Lewis acidity of the support. We determined that it is the increase in Brønsted acidity that enhances the demethoxylation and dehydroxylation reactions, not the total number of acid sites. Therefore, it was determined that for NiCu catalysts, a balance is required not only between the acidity of the support but also between the Lewis/Brønsted ratio and the amount of Cu within the alloy. Taking this into account, a highly efficient catalyst for guaiacol HDO was obtained: the monometallic Ni catalyst supported on the aluminosilicate Al-Si(0.53), Ni/Al-Si(0.53). This balance of Lewis/Brønsted acid sites with the metallic sites also allowed the monometallic Cu catalysts to produce cyclohexane under conditions that were not possible using Al2O3 as a support, see Fig. 21. This is because Cu sites together with Brønsted sites enhance demethylation by promoting hydrogen transfer from one molecule to another and hydrogen transfer within the same molecule [128].
