Finally, the sum of the reaction products yields for the synthesized catalysts at iso-conversion of guaiacol, Fig. 20, of any of the catalysts was less than 25 %yield, when theoretically it should be equal to conversion (25 %). This is due to the unquantified products (gaseous products) and coke deposits on the catalyst, see Figure S34. No alkylated products were observed. The error of the carbon balances as a function of reaction time is presented in Figures S19 to S33. Monometallic Cu catalyst presented the highest deviation with a maximum value of 0.11 while in the bimetallic catalysts the error tends to increase in the catalysts with high Cu loading (NiCu(0.75)), where products of the deoxygenation pathway were observed, such as 1,2 dimethoxybenzene. Therefore, it is possible that this difference in the carbon balance was due to the formation of methylated species released during deoxygenation reactions, e.g., the formation of catechol, or to the formation of coke generated by the strong adsorption of oxygenated compounds produced during the deoxygenation pathway, which are more prone to coke formation by autopolymerization [139]. According to Zanuttini et al.[140] in the HDO of m-cresol, coke formation is related to the hydrogenation capacity of the catalyst, since by having a lower capacity to hydrogenate the aromatic ring, the parallel reactions of partially hydrogenated compounds such as cyclohexadiene that give rise to coke become more relevant. In this sense, it would make sense that Cu, having a lower hydrogenation capacity than Ni, generates a greater amount not only of methylated species through the production of catechol, but also of carbonaceous deposits. However, further studies are required to understand the relationship between Cu content and catalyst deactivation. This result further confirms the ineffectiveness of monometallic Cu catalysts for HDO reactions, since they not only decrease the selectivity towards hydrodeoxygenated products, but also generate a greater amount of gaseous products (such as CO2, methane or light C2-C4 hydrocarbons) and coke [141,142]. 4 Conclusions In this work, a systematic analysis of the effect of the Cu/(Ni+Cu) molar ratio on the HDO of guaiacol was performed using a batch reactor operated at 250 °C and pH2 = 6.9 MPa and considering the possible presence of mass transfer limitations in the reaction. Three different supports were used: Al2O3 and two aluminosilicates with lower Lewis acidity than Al2O3 and a small fraction of Brønsted acid sites. The synthesis method used generated a wide size distribution of the metallic particles in the catalysts, with the formation of large Cu-rich and small Ni-rich NiCu alloy particles in which the Cu coats the Ni particles as the Cu/(Ni+Cu) ratio increases. It was demonstrated that monometallic Ni catalysts present higher conversion and selectivity towards the hydrogen-mediated pathway in the guaiacol HDO process than NiCu catalysts, being Ni the metal that directs the reaction pathway. In fact, a monometallic Ni catalyst supported on an aluminosilicate was obtained, which rapidly converts guaiacol to cyclohexane under lower temperature conditions than those used in conventional works. Monometallic Cu was less active than the other catalysts but was able to convert guaiacol to the deoxygenation pathway, producing small fractions of cyclohexane when aluminosilicates were used as supports. For bimetallic catalysts, it was observed that increasing the Cu/(Ni+Cu) molar ratio leads to a decrease in the initial reaction rate due to the enrichment of the metallic particles with Cu, which migrates more easily to the surface of the metallic particle, and not due to the presence of NiO as has been reported for NiCu catalysts on other supports. Additionally, it was observed that larger Cu-rich NiCu alloy particles decreased the selectivity towards the hydrogenation-mediated pathway and generate deoxygenation pathway products such as 1,2-dimethoxybenzene due to surface enrichment with Cu. Furthermore, the results suggest that the presence of Brønsted acidity in the support, due to the modification of Al₂O₃ with SiO₂, improves the selectivity to cyclohexane in all materials because it promotes the cyclohexanol dehydroxylation reaction, which has been postulated as the rate-determining step of guaiacol HDO. Finally, the results lead to the conclusion that for NiCu catalysts, a balance between the support acidity, the Lewis/Brønsted ratio, and the amount of Cu within the alloy is required. This balance of Lewis/Brønsted acid sites with the metallic sites also allowed the monometallic Cu catalysts to produce cyclohexane via demethylation reactions under conditions that were not possible using Al2O3 as support. coredata.dc:description: Bio-oils obtained from rapid pyrolysis have emerged as a renewable energy source, but their high content of oxygenated molecules gives them unwanted properties for their use as green fuels. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is the process used to improve their quality by removing oxygen heteroatoms from them. At the research stage, HDO is commonly studied with model molecules such as guaiacol. Bimetallic supported NiCu catalysts are efficient for diverse hydrogenations. However, published studies do not allow concluding whether supported NiCu catalysts lead to green fuels which are free from oxygen heteroatoms. For this reason, we systematically studied the properties of Al2O3 and Al2O3-SiO2 supported NiCu catalysts for the HDO of guaiacol in a batch reactor at representative process conditions; 250°C and p H 2 = 6.9 MPa . In general, supported monometallic Ni catalysts were the most active among all catalysts. Furthermore, the addition of Cu promoted the formation of large Cu-rich alloy particles that decreased the apparent initial reaction rate regardless of the support. This effect was stronger when aluminosilicates were used as catalytic support. In addition, Ni was responsible for directing the reaction route towards the hydrogenation pathway in the bimetallic catalysts, while Cu monometallic catalysts followed the direct deoxygenation route. On the other hand, the modification of the support increased the formation of green cyclohexane, even in monometallic Cu catalysts, allowing to obtain a highly active and selective monometallic Ni catalyst towards the production of cyclohexane.
